title: Chapter 8 – Working with Text: Strings Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 8. Test your understanding of strings, indexing, slicing, methods, and f-strings.

questions.prompt: In Python, what is a string?

options.label: A number you can add and subtract.
A secret code Python cannot read.

explanations.overview: A string (str) represents text characters written inside quotes.

byOptionId.a: Numbers are values without quotes; strings are text inside quotes.
byOptionId.b: Correct – strings are pieces of text inside quotation marks.
byOptionId.d: Lists can store many types, but that's different from strings.

explanations.overview: Indexing starts at 0, so index 1 is the second character.

byOptionId.a: Index 0 is 'H'. Index 1 is the next character.
byOptionId.b: This would be a slice, not a single index.
byOptionId.c: Correct – 'A' is the character at index 1.

explanations.overview: Slicing text[start:end] takes characters from start up to but not including end.

byOptionId.b: That's just the first character, not 0:3.
byOptionId.d: Those are the last three letters, from a different slice.

explanations.overview: The .upper() method makes all letters uppercase.

byOptionId.a: That is the original string, not uppercased.
byOptionId.b: Only the first letter capitalized would not be full upper case.
byOptionId.d: This is just the word 'upper', not the result of the method.

questions.prompt: You have `name = "Mia"`. Which line correctly uses an f-string to print `Hello, Mia!`?

explanations.overview: F-strings start with f and insert variable values into the text.

byOptionId.a: Without the f, {name} will not be replaced.
byOptionId.b: Correct – this is the proper f-string syntax.
byOptionId.c: This works, but it is not an f-string.
byOptionId.d: Here "name" is inside quotes, so it is just text, not the variable.
